author: The Telegraph
title: Who will be speaking at Britain's Smart Cities?
text: Find out more about the Britain's Smart Cities » Guest speakers Boris Johnson MP Mayor of London Boris Johnson was elected Mayor of London in 2008 and re-elected in 2012. Under his tenure, crime in London has fallen 17pc, the capital has seen record investment in transport and staged what are widely acknowledged to be the most successful Olympic and Paralympic Games ever. Mr Johnson, who was elected Conservative MP for Uxbridge & South Ruislip in May, made jobs and growth his key second-term priority. Last year he launched his 2020 Vision for London based on prioritising house building, investment in road and rail infrastructure, support for financial services and the tech sector, and low and stable tax rates. Steve Turner Head of Future Cities Manchester City Council LinkedIn Steve Turner is strategic lead for the design, coordination and delivery of the Manchester Future Cities programme. He led the design of Manchester’s €24m (£17m) EU Lighthouse submission, Triangulum, and is currently overseeing the development of an open innovation programme in conjunction with the BBC. More recently Turner secured a number of strategic relationships with China, leading work on the EU-China Smart City Forum, as well as establishing joint collaboration projects with Digital China and Wuhan. He has held a number of external positions, advising both the UK Government and the European Commission on their respective Smart Cities initiatives. Geoff Snelson Director of strategy Milton Keynes Council LinkedIn Geoff Snelson has worked at Milton Keynes Council since 1998. His responsibilities include corporate strategy and performance, communications and external relations, economic development and inward investment. He’s also involved in influencing strategies and major projects to secure the long-term economic success and sustainability of Milton Keynes, which is the fastest growing place in the UK. Snelson’s current projects include the Milton Keynes Future City programme, varied smart city projects, intelligent (and driverless) mobility and major arts and sports events – including being a host city for Rugby World Cup 2015. Stephen Hilton Connecting Bristol Bristol City Council LinkedIn Stephen Hilton is interested in what makes cities smart and liveable. As Bristol City Council’s first director of futures, he is leading the council’s efforts towards better city living. During his directorship, Stephen has helped Bristol to become European Green Capital 2015, a Rockefeller Global Resilient city, a Super Connected City and an internationally recognised Smart City. He has lead its work within open data, autonomous vehicles and the “internet of things” and managed the Bristol City Council consultation and e-participation team. Bristol is a leader in the area of local e-government and has been named as European City for e-Democracy. Enrico Motta Professor of knowledge technologies Open University LinkedIn Prof Enrico Motta has a PhD in artificial intelligence from the Open University, where he is currently a professor in knowledge technologies. His research focuses on making sense of large amounts of data using data integration, pattern extraction and visualization. He has authored over 300 refereed publications. He currently leads MK:Smart, a £16m initiative that aims to tackle key barriers to economic growth in Milton Keynes. Prof Motta is editor-in-chief of the International Journal of Human-Computer Studies and, over the years, has advised strategic research boards and governments in the UK, US, Netherlands, Italy, Austria, Finland, and Estonia. Dan Byles Vice president of corporate development Living PlanIT LinkedIn Dan Byles chairs the independent UK smart city trade association SmarterUK, bringing together stakeholders from across all sectors, championing smart city development within the UK and helping to shape the policy environment for smart city solutions. Before joining Living PlanIT, Byles was an MP serving on the Energy and Climate Change Select Committee and the Science and Technology Committee. He has strong expertise in energy, environment and clean-tech policy, serving on the Parliamentary Bill Committee for the Energy Act 2014 and chairing a number of high profile All Party Parliamentary Groups. Byles was the founding chairman of the All Party Parliamentary Smart Cities Group and a member of the UK Government Ministerial Smart City Forum.
